content.title: Thoracentesis
content.summary: Percutaneous procedure to remove pleural fluid for diagnostic analysis or therapeutic symptom relief, using anatomical landmarks or ultrasound guidance
key_points: Needle aspiration of pleural fluid through chest wall
Diagnostic: analyze fluid to determine cause of effusion
Therapeutic: relieve dyspnea from large effusions (drain up to 1.5L)
Light's criteria distinguish transudates from exudates
Complications: pneumothorax (5-15% blind, 1% ultrasound-guided), bleeding, re-expansion pulmonary edema
Contraindications: bleeding diathesis, overlying cellulitis, very small effusion

statement.text: Thoracentesis is a bedside procedure involving needle aspiration of pleural fluid through the chest wall. It serves both diagnostic purposes (determining the etiology of pleural effusion via fluid analysis) and therapeutic purposes (relieving dyspnea from large effusions). Ultrasound guidance significantly reduces complication rates and is now standard of care. Light's criteria, comparing pleural fluid to serum protein and LDH levels, differentiate transudative from exudative effusions and guide further workup.
statement.formal: Light's Criteria (Exudate if ANY): Pleural protein/serum protein >0.5 | Pleural LDH/serum LDH >0.6 | Pleural LDH >2/3 upper limit normal serum LDH

explanation.intuition: When fluid accumulates between the lung and chest wall (pleural effusion), it can compress the lung and cause shortness of breath. Thoracentesis removes this fluid with a needle. By analyzing the fluid, we can determine why it accumulated - is it 'watery' fluid leaking from low protein states (heart failure, cirrhosis) or 'inflammatory' fluid from infection, cancer, or other diseases? This distinction guides treatment.
explanation.key_insight: Light's criteria are highly sensitive (98%) for identifying exudates but less specific (83%). Some transudates (especially with diuretic use) may be misclassified as exudates. When Light's criteria suggest exudate but clinical picture suggests transudate, check serum-effusion albumin gradient (>1.2 g/dL suggests transudate) or serum-effusion protein gradient (>3.1 g/dL suggests transudate).
explanation.technical_details: The procedure involves inserting a needle perpendicular to the chest wall, just above the rib (to avoid the neurovascular bundle running below each rib). The needle enters the pleural space and fluid is aspirated. For therapeutic thoracentesis, a catheter may be advanced to allow drainage. Maximum removal of 1-1.5L per session reduces re-expansion pulmonary edema risk.

definitions_glossary.thoracentesis: Percutaneous needle aspiration of pleural fluid through chest wall for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes
definitions_glossary.pleural_effusion: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in pleural space between lung and chest wall
definitions_glossary.transudative_effusion: Low-protein effusion from systemic conditions (heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome)
definitions_glossary.exudative_effusion: Protein-rich effusion from local pleural disease (infection, malignancy, inflammation)
definitions_glossary.lights_criteria: Three biochemical criteria comparing pleural fluid to serum to classify effusions
definitions_glossary.serum_albumin_gradient: Serum albumin minus pleural albumin; >1.2 g/dL suggests transudate (used when Light's misleading)
definitions_glossary.ldh: Lactate dehydrogenase; enzyme marker of cellular injury and inflammation
definitions_glossary.empyema: Purulent pleural infection requiring chest tube drainage
definitions_glossary.malignant_effusion: Effusion caused by cancer cells in pleural space
definitions_glossary.reexpansion_pulmonary_edema: Rare complication after rapid drainage of large effusion; presents with cough, dyspnea
definitions_glossary.ultrasound_guidance: Real-time imaging to identify fluid pocket and avoid lung or solid organs
definitions_glossary.pneumothorax: Air in pleural space; complication from inadvertent lung puncture

pathophysiology.mechanism: Pleural effusions develop when fluid production exceeds absorption. Transudates result from altered hydrostatic or oncotic pressures (heart failure, cirrhosis). Exudates result from pleural inflammation or impaired lymphatic drainage (infection, malignancy, autoimmune). Thoracentesis samples this fluid for diagnostic analysis and can remove large volumes therapeutically.

fluid_formation.transudative: Increased hydrostatic pressure (CHF) or decreased oncotic pressure (cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome)
fluid_formation.exudative: Increased capillary permeability (infection, malignancy) or impaired lymphatic drainage

indications.diagnostic: New pleural effusion of unknown etiology; effusion not explained by clinical context
indications.therapeutic: Large symptomatic effusion causing dyspnea; repeated therapeutic drainage for recurrent effusions

relative: Very small effusion (<1 cm on lateral decubitus)

exudate_if_any: Pleural LDH > 2/3 upper limit of normal serum LDH

additional_fluid_tests.glucose: Low in empyema, rheumatoid, malignancy, TB
additional_fluid_tests.cytology: For malignancy (60-90% sensitivity with repeat sampling)
additional_fluid_tests.ada: Adenosine deaminase; elevated in TB pleuritis

procedure_technique.positioning: Sitting upright, leaning forward over bedside table
procedure_technique.ultrasound: Mark largest fluid pocket; identify diaphragm and underlying organs
procedure_technique.site: Posterolateral chest, 1-2 intercostal spaces below fluid level
procedure_technique.insertion: Perpendicular to skin, just above rib to avoid neurovascular bundle
procedure_technique.aspiration: Diagnostic: 30-50 mL; Therapeutic: up to 1-1.5 L

post_procedure.cxr: Not routinely needed if ultrasound-guided and asymptomatic; obtain if symptoms develop
post_procedure.complications_watch: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea suggesting pneumothorax

definition.@value: Percutaneous needle aspiration of pleural fluid for diagnostic analysis or therapeutic symptom relief

skos.scopeNote: Covers diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis, Light's criteria interpretation, and ultrasound guidance
skos.example: A 65-year-old with new pleural effusion undergoes ultrasound-guided thoracentesis; fluid shows protein ratio 0.6, LDH ratio 0.8, lymphocyte predominance; cytology reveals adenocarcinoma cells

learning_objectives: Apply Light's criteria to classify pleural effusions
Describe the technique and complications of thoracentesis
Recognize when ultrasound guidance is indicated
clinical_pearls: Light's criteria: exudate if protein ratio >0.5 OR LDH ratio >0.6 OR LDH >2/3 ULN
Ultrasound guidance reduces pneumothorax risk from 5-15% to <1% - use it!
If Light's says exudate but you suspect transudate, check albumin gradient (>1.2 = transudate)
Pleural pH <7.2 or glucose <60 suggests complicated effusion needing drainage
Limit drainage to 1-1.5L per session to reduce re-expansion pulmonary edema risk
Insert needle ABOVE rib to avoid neurovascular bundle below each rib
common_misconceptions: All effusions need thoracentesis (false - known cause like CHF may not need tap if bilateral, clinical context clear)
One negative cytology excludes malignancy (false - sensitivity ~60%; may need repeat or pleural biopsy)
CXR always needed post-procedure (false - not if US-guided, asymptomatic, no air aspirated)
